page.title: 19Tourism
page.content: Much has been done by the National Trust to restore Hughenden Manor as it was in Disraeli's time.Red distemper once more covers the walls of the Hall where the woodwork is again varnished and grained.When the new wooden floor was laid in the dining room because of wet mould,the remains of an Elizabethan brick floor of the original farmhouse were found.In the renovation of the study in the winter of 1983-4 a Victorian photograph was copied to position furniture and old blocks were used to print the wallpaper.The furniture in here is all original.Soon the present tea-room is to be restored to its original use as "Dizzy's" bedroom. The house is filled with Disraeli memorablia including his "Gallery of Friendship" and the mourning note- paper used after the death of Mary-Anne
